Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rhizosphere priming and C-N dynamics in grassland ecosystems in transition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rhizosphere priming, the focus of this study, is the process by which living roots affect the potential for soils to store and release carbon and nitrogen. On a global basis, soils store twice as much carbon as is in the atmosphere and regulate the nitrogen supply to maintain plant productivity while preventing excess nitrogen losses. Laboratory studies indicate that rhizosphere priming is likely a key control on soil CO2 emissions and the release of nitrogen from organic matter. However, the control of rhizosphere priming on soil carbon and nitrogen transformations in real ecosystems has been difficult to study and is not well understood. This is important because many environmental changes could alter rhizosphere priming, with potentially large consequences for carbon storage and nitrogen cycling. By measuring carbon and nitrogen isotope tracers in plants and soils, this study will follow the fate of different carbon and nitrogen sources and separate their contributions the functioning of the soil in grasslands of the central United States. This study also uses plants with different kinds of root characteristics to figure out the different influences plants can have on rhizosphere priming. Over three years, this study will address two main questions: (1) What is the magnitude of rhizosphere priming on the breakdown of organic matter under realistic soil conditions? and (2) How do different plant and soil characteristics affect priming across seasons, types of plants and different soils? This project is that start of a comprehensive effort to decipher and ground truth the important roles of of roots in actual grassland ecosystems.

The results of this project will help us understand how changes in plants and environmental conditions affect air quality and the loss of nitrogen from soils. It will train nine undergraduate students, three graduate students, and a post-doctoral scientist. Recruitment of participants will focus on underrepresented groups and build on existing programs in California, Kansas and Oklahoma to increase the diversity of the project participants. Results will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses in the three states and project data will be made available on a web site. This project will also help to enhance public education and awareness and to inform the general public of the importance of roots in providing essential services from our grasslands. Finally, the location and visibility of the experiment at the Konza Prairie Long-Term Ecological Research site in Kansas offers unique opportunities for public education, including development of modules for the schoolyard programs and other outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soils are an important sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) and more carbon (C) is stored in the Earth?s soil than in the atmosphere. Microbes are responsible for processing soil organic carbon, but plants affect soil microbial communities in numerous ways that can alter the processing and storage of carbon in the soils. As a result, plant roots and associated soil processes are a critical component of the global C budget. Understanding how plant roots alter microbial communities, soil processes and the breakdown of soil organic matter is critical for predicting changes in soil carbon storage under changing plant cover or changing environmental conditions. This project aimed to provide new insights into plant-soil interactions and the role of rhizosphere processes on soil C storage using a combination of greenhouse and field experiments. Our approach includes the use of plants and soils with different C isotope signatures in order to separate the soil C and CO2 derived directly from plant roots and the C and CO2 from organic matter that was previously stored in the soil. This allowed us to follow the fate of root-derived and soil-derived C and separate their contributions to total CO2 released from the soil.

In field experiments, we found that the magnitude of the rhizosphere effects varied with plant species and with root biomass. In general, greater root biomass was correlated with higher rates of soil organic C decomposition compared to unplanted controls. The species with the highest root biomass (Cornus drummundii) had the highest positive rhizosphere priming effect, and increased the breakdown of soil C by 33%. In contract, the species with the lowest root biomass (Juniperus virginiana) reduced soil organic C decomposition by 55%. Other species examined had rhizosphere priming effects close to zero. In a greenhouse experiment, we also investigated how species-specific plant-soil feedbacks affect rates of soil organic C decomposition using two C3 grass species (Bromus inermis and Pascopyrum smithii) grown in C4?derived tallgrass prairie soil with a distinct isotopic C signature. We found significant effects of plant species identity on total soil respiration and on the breakdown of previously stored soil organic matter, though these effects varied over successive growing cycles. These results are likely due to the differential effects of these plant species on soil microbial communities. In addition, the effects of the initial plant species identity on the microbial communities was found to last through multiple growing cycles, even when the plant species identity was changed. These results suggest that plant-soil history is important for SOM mineralization and that changes in soil microbial community caused by shifts in plant species composition can have lasting effects on ecosystem processes. Collectively, these results indicate that the direction and magnitude of rhizosphere priming is species specific, and the biogeochemical effects of plant community changes are likely to vary with the plant species involved.

This project provided training for 3 graduate students and 9 undergraduate students. Results of this project were presented at multiple local, regional and national meetings. In addition, we incorporated data from this project into outreach programs designed to inform the general public about the importance of plant-soil interactions for carbon sequestration and other vital ecosystem services. For example, Results were presented to state representatives at the Kansas Capitol Graduate Research Summit, and presented to the general public as part of the "Science on Tap" series affiliated with the KSU Science Communications Initiative (http://www.k-state.edu/scicomm/).
